newsitem.title: USA: Stallone's "Cop Land" opens at top of U.S. box office.
newsitem.headline: Stallone's "Cop Land" opens at top of U.S. box office.

text.p: The Sylvester Stallone police drama "Cop Land" captured the top spot at the weekend box office, while "Air Force One" and "Conspiracy Theory" were in hot pursuit, according to studio estimates released Sunday.

"Cop Land" earned about $13.0 million for the Friday-to-Sunday period, while "Air Force One" held steady in second with $12.6 million and last week's box office champ "Conspiracy Theory" slipped to third with $12.3 million.

Rounding out the top five were "Event Horizon," a new science fiction horror release starring Laurence Fishburne and Sam Neill. It earned $9.5 million. "Spawn" and "George of the Jungle" each claimed fifth spot, reporting $5.1 million and $5.0 million, respectively. Final data will be released Monday.

Stallone, best known for playing gruff action heroes in big-budget films, turned down his regular $20 million pay check to star in "Cop Land," a relatively inexpensive movie about police corruption in a small town.
In the film, he plays a slow-witted sheriff opposite Robert De Niro, Harvey Keitel and Ray Liotta. The movie was released by Miramax Films, a unit of Walt Disney Co..
The movie sets a new Miramax record for an opening weekend. The previous record was held by "Pulp Fiction," which opened to a reported $9.3 million in October 1994.
"This is fantasy time come true," said Mark Gill, Miramax's president of marketing. "It's very, very nice."
He said in an interview the film attracted a "bizarre combination" of young action fans as well as discerning moviegoers looking for a "smart, intelligent Miramax film."

"Cop Land" averaged $5,822 from 2,233 screens, the highest average in the top 10. Still, the average paled against those for recent previous number ones such as "Conspiracy Theory," "Air Force One" and "Men in Black."

Critics were generally favorable towards the movie, which represents the second feature for writer/director James Mangold. According to a Variety poll of reviewers in New York, Los Angeles, Chicago and Washington DC, 20 critics liked it, 10 did not and 15 were mixed.

In its fourth weekend, Harrison Ford's "Air Force One" exhibited strong staying power as its gross slipped just 29 percent from last weekend. The 24-day total stands at $130.6 million. The film is released by Columbia Pictures, a unit of Sony Corp..
"Conspiracy Theory" fell 36 percent in its second weekend, as its 10-day total rose to $47 million. The Mel Gibson/Julia Roberts thriller is released by Warner Bros., a unit of Time Warner Inc..

"Event Horizon" averaged a modest $4,111 per screen from its first three days. According to Wayne Lewellen, president of distribution at Paramount Pictures, which released the film, the $9.5 million gross was above expectations. He said it was difficult to make the film stand out above pictures such as "Men in Black," "Spawn" and the upcoming "Mimic," all of which are targeted at the young male action crowd. Paramount is a unit of Viacom Inc..
According to Variety, just two critics liked "Event Horizon," while 10 did not and 11 were mixed.
New Line Cinema and Disney each claimed fifth spot for their respective films "Spawn" and "George of the Jungle," although New Line's figure was higher. New Line is a unit of Time Warner.

The one other major wide release was Warner Bros.' Shaquille O'Neal action film "Steel," which opened well out of the top 10 with a paltry $900,000, or $714 average. It's the second consecutive flop for the basketball player, after last year's "Kazaam," in which he played a genie.
